Hi Tim, please let me know what you think of this idea:
How to move allot of people & supplies fast to Mars. Elon has people that engineered the Falcon Heavy which is three boosters tied together. Why not three super heavy boosters to get starship not only away from earth gravity but to get starship on its way moving at a very fast rate. Then the starship decouples and the three connected boosters go back to earth, slow up and return uncoupled like they normally would have. In the meantime starship is making good time without expending almost no fuel. When starship is almost to Mars, it opens up it’s clamshell front end to release its main payload. At that point, starship uses the slingshot method around Mars to be on its way back to earth smoking hot. Fast. The payload that was dropped off has a heat shield and slows down in the atmosphere and then uses parachutes then lastly thrusters like Blue Origin does. This sacrifices some weight at liftoff but the starship doesn’t have to lift off from Mars. Plus starship returns back to earth faster.

Tim, some of us are investing significant money into companies (like SpaceX), not for potential return, but for the prospect of accelerating an awesome future for all mankind and directly supporting leaders like the team Elon has formed that are working brilliantly to realize our dreams.  We need to encourage this!

32:25 - One of the things about Inspiration 4 that I find most amazing is that Hayley Arceneaux is the first ever "didn't seek it" astronaut.

Before her, every single person who has ever been in space is someone who made an effort to get to where they could go to space. Applied to government astronaut training programs, paid for a seat on a "tourist" flight - even Sian and Chris "applied" for this flight, with Sian being a NASA astronaut finalist before, and Chris buying a raffle ticket. (As did I.)

Hayley is the only person (so far) to have been just asked "hey, you want to go to space?" with no prior effort made to get into a space program. That, to me, is the threshold that indicates we have reached "true space tourism."

Yes, it still takes months of preparation for an orbital flight, and weeks for a suborbital; and it's still ridiculously expensive; but we're there. We're at the point where ANYONE can just "go to space." (As long as you have a benefactor or can afford it.)

At this point, I am imagining that by the time I retire, an orbital flight will be one of those "once a lifetime" trips that are still expensive - but within the reach of the middle class as a 'once a lifetime' for those who want to go. Like an airline flight was in the late 1940s just pre-jet-age to early jet-age.

Given that Ingenuity seems to be way more durable than expected, I wonder if there's a way to use it as a useful companion to Perseverance? You'd want to keep it a safe distance from the hugely expensive rover in case of accidents, but it seems plausible that it could reconnoitre the terrain in advance of the rover to produce better autonomous driving maps, for example. Even if it doesn't last long it could be useful and also provide valuable experience in using companion drones.

17:28 just a fun little FYI, SN15 didn't lose an engine on ascent, rather the internal computer recognized that the header tank pressure was slightly lower than nominal, so in order to avoid the risk of eating your own engine like SN8, they only ignited 2.
